You ask -- you wanted to ask him questions yourself, they said following the Corbin, they do not permit that.
You then said that that violated Section 205 -- 105 of the Georgia Constitution and also Article 6 and Article 14 of the Constitution.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What you have raised here, what you raised in that as I read it, as I understand you that's what you said, you say that it deprived him of the right to counsel contrary to the Fourteenth Amendment for its federal (Inaudible) to allow him to make the statement and to deny his -- him the benefit of having his counsel guide and assist him by asking questions.
Yes, sir.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's the question you raised.
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: -- and insisted.
He is denied the right and benefit of counsel to help him out.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You say that the mere fact that it permitted him to make a statement sworn or unsworn is immaterial.
That if they permit him to make statements, you don't have to reach the question whether they could do what they make him competent or incompetent, they have (Voice Overlap) passed on.
Georgia said that he can make a statement.
You say that when they go that far, the amendment of Federal Constitution steps in and say you got to give him the benefit of counsel to ask questions.
Mr. Justice Black, as I said yesterday, I would --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Was there anything (Voice Overlap) would raise for counsel about that.
Yes, sir.
I said that it is -- is unconstitutional on the face of that particular code section -- that particular code section.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But I --I understand it.
But you --
No, it doesn't say in that code section about the -- anything except requesting on his counsel's part.
It says he shall not be subject to cross-examination, but it does not say anything about asking him any questions by his own counsel.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Voice Overlap) Georgia, well they've interpreted to this meaning that you cannot ask questions.
That's right.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We have to accept that.
And they have also --

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: We'll accept that and you say, and since that if the law in Georgia, they allow him to make a statement but don't allow his counsel to ask him questions it deprives of the right to counsel unconstitutionally.
Yes, sir and in the sense discretionary with the trial judge goes a step further.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It's the same thing.
That is saying that it's up to him -- that the trial judge to decide whether he shall have the benefit of counsel or not.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Do you think he has constitutional right to examine, to have -- have his lawyer ask him the question, whether the judge wants to do it on his discretion or not?
Yes, sir.
It's up to the judge.
Judge can say, yes, you can help this client and the other lawyer, you can't help that client.
And that to me would be entirely discretionary and discriminatory.
Also I said yesterday, I certainly would far rather for the sake of the State and for the sake of the defendant to have the thing that he is just like it is in federal court or any other court.
That would be the far better way to get to real justice would be held like every other state has it and like the federal court has it.

But that will be something the legislature would have to enact at and I think they would do it immediately if anything has ever happened to code section 38-415, because even a trial judge here, it says no matter however logical they all feel that way about it.
It would be much better.
Thank you very much.
